Project Description  The  Project  will  rehabilitate  public  infrastructure  damaged  by 
severe landslides and floods during the spring and summer of 
2003. The affected infrastructure includes (i) roads and bridges, 
(ii) power distribution lines, and (iii) schools. The Project will also 
provide municipal infrastructure in two resettlement centers that 
the Government is establishing for disaster-affected people. 
   
Rationale  The  Project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Policy on Rehabilitation 
Assistance After Disasters. There is an urgent need to help the 
Government  cope  with  the  disasters,  especially  given  the 
country’s constrained fiscal situation. The Project will assist in 
rehabilitating  damaged  public  infrastructure,  and  ensure  that 
natural disasters do not disrupt social and economic development 
in project areas. 
   
Objectives and Scope  The immediate purpose of the Project is to assist the Government 
to restore economic and social activity quickly in the communities 
of four oblasts (provinces) struck by landslides and floods by 
rehabilitating damaged public infrastructure. The long-term goal of 
the  Project  is  to  help  sustain  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction in the country. The Project comprises four components: 
 
Roads  and  bridges.  Rehabilitating  five  damaged  roads  and 
rebuilding ten damaged bridges in the oblasts of Chui, Issyk-Kul, 
Jalal-Abad, and Osh.  
 
Electricity. Rehabilitating and rebuilding about 21 kilometers on 
four damaged power distribution lines, as well as replacing three 
electrical transformer stations in the oblasts of Chui and Osh. 
 
Schools.  Building  four  schools  and  providing  furniture  and 
facilities in areas less prone to natural disasters in the oblasts of 
Chui and Osh. 
 
Municipal Infrastructure. Building municipal infrastructure (on-
site roads, power lines, water supply, and drainage systems) in 
two  permanent  resettlement  centers  that  the  Government  is 
establishing for disaster-affected people in Osh.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Emergency Rehabilitation Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES1 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The Kyrgyz Republic is a small, mountainous country (over 90% of the total territory is 
mountainous) and is vulnerable to natural disasters. Floods and landslides are major concerns 
because of monsoon rains, seismic activity, steep slopes, fragile soils, and human action.  
Such natural disasters would cause damage to inhabitants and physical  infrastructure, thus 
posing a threat to the country’s economic and social development. Effective response to natural 
disasters to minimize the damage is one of the major challenges faced by the country. 
 
3.  Roads. The country is landlocked, and road transport accounts for about 94% of freight 
movement and almost all passenger traffic. The country’s road network covers all seven oblasts 
(provinces),  and  provides  connections  to  far-flung communities and neighboring countries.  
The road network comprises about 18,900 kilometers (km) of roads: 9,900 km of state roads 
and 9,000 km of local roads, about 40% of which are sealed, 50% gravel, and 10% earth. Traffic 
has fallen substantially since 1991 because of economic contraction following the breakup of 
the former Soviet Union, although the transport recovered somewhat after 1995. In 2001 
passenger and freight turnovers accounted for 57% and 20% of their respective 1990 levels.2 
The Government has made substantial efforts in road sector reform. All 29 road construction 
enterprises and 74 of 86 road transport service providers were privatized. Most national holding 
companies that had exercised control over transport operations were abolished. The market for 
freight  transport  services  is  becoming  increasingly  competitive.  However,  the  Government 
continues to exert strong influence over intercity passenger transport and play a large role in 
freight  transport  through  its  holdings  in  joint-stock  companies  and  its  regulation  capacity.  
The existing road network is adequate for the country’s development needs; the major sector 
issue is proper rehabilitation and maintenance to preserve the existing network. The Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been  actively  providing  assistance  to  improve  road  sector 
performance.3 
 
4.  Electricity. The country has a large hydroelectric potential with more than 163,000 
gigawatt-hours  (GWh)  per  year,  of  which  less  than  10%  is  presently  exploited.  Primary 
electricity production from hydropower accounts for more than 80% of the total energy output. 
The country is a net exporter of electricity. In 2002, it generated 14,750 GWh compared with 
domestic consumption of 11,500 GWh, with about 10% of annual production exported to 
neighboring countries. Following the split of the power monopoly, Kyrgyzenergo in 2001, there 
are six power sector comprises: one generation company (JSC Generation Stations), one 
transmission company (JSC National Grid), and four distribution companies operating in the 
oblasts of Chui and Talas, Osh, Jalal-Abad, and Naryn and Issy-Kul, respectively. About 98% of 
the population is connected to the power grid. The Government has initiated power sector 
reform.  The  Energy  Law  was  enacted  to  provide  a  framework  for  sector  regulation  and

5.  Education. The Kyrgyz education system comprises five principal levels of education 
and is based on the former Soviet system.  Government  statistics  indicate  that  the  gross 
enrollment ratio for primary education is 97.5% in 1998, with virtually identical rates for boys and 
girls. School enrollment and educational quality have deteriorated over the past decade due to 
the decline in income, depleted stocks of textbooks and other learning materials, an underpaid 
teaching force, and physical deterioration of schools. Although the Ministry of Education and 
Culture (MOEC) only reports 2,500 children out of school in 2001, independent estimates 
suggest far higher figures.5 About 40% of respondent school children failed a literacy test in a 
recent survey conducted by the United Nations. Education sector reform has been pursued 
since 1992 with the promulgation of the Education Law. Major measures adopted include  
(i) new curriculum, textbooks, and learning materials; (ii) stronger pupil assessment and teacher 
training; (iii) delegated responsibility for management and financing of primary and secondary 
schools  to  local  bodies;  and  (iv)  upgraded  and  rehabilitated  facilities  and  equipment.  
The Government has recently developed a concept paper for education development to 2010, 
providing  the  key  policy  and  strategic  framework  for  education.  Nevertheless,  the  sector 
experiences several main problems: rising inequalities in access to, and declining quality of, 
education  services;  low  teacher  motivation  due  to  low  salaries;  and  shortcomings  in  the 
delegation of responsibilities for primary and secondary schools to local bodies. ADB has been 
the  main  source  of  external  assistance  to  the  education  sector  since  the  country’s 
independence in 1991.6 
 
6.  The country is experiencing severe fiscal and debt constraints, due to the accumulation 
of the public sector budget deficits during 1993- 1996 and the large devaluation of the som 
following the Russian financial crisis during 1997- 1998. At the end of 2002, the country’s 
external debt stock was equivalent to about $1.8 billion (111% of gross domestic product 
[GDP]), of which about $1.6 billion were public or government-guaranteed loans.7 The large 
external debt has become an excessive burden on the fiscal system, severely restricted the 
Government’s  capacity  to  borrow  abroad,  and  limited  its  ability  to  effectively  respond  to 
emergency needs with its own resources.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
7.  The Kyrgyz Republic suffered from severe landslides and floods during the spring and 
summer of 2003 due to heavy rains. The Government’s meteorological records show that 
rainfall in the oblasts of Jalal-Abad and Osh from March- June 2003 was on average about 50% 
higher than in normal years (Table 1), and over 30 millimeters (mm) of precipitation fell in a one-
hour period in Chui oblast on 21 June 2003, a record high. Rivers and streams broke their 
banks under the increased water volume and silt load. Torrential rains also triggered landslides 
because soils were saturated by the rains and slid down steep slopes. About 1,000 landslides 
occurred during the first eight months of 2003, compared with an average of 15- 20 landslides 
during the similar period in a normal year.

8.  The landslides and floods of 2003 have caused the country’s worst damage since 1994. 
According to the Government, 43 people were killed, 1,088 families lost their houses, around 
6,000  hectares  of  agricultural  land  were  damaged,  and  more  than  300,000  people  were 
affected. Total damage cost more than Som566 million ($13.5 million), almost 1% of GDP. 
Natural disasters also destroyed or severely damaged roads, bridges, power lines, irrigation 
facilities, schools, and hospitals. An assessment of the damage to roads, bridges, power 
distribution facilities, and schools is provided below. 
 
9.  Roads and bridges. About 55.5 km of roads and 21 bridges were destroyed or severely 
damaged. The damage was particularly serious in the oblasts of Chui, Jalal-Abad, and Osh. In 
Osh, huge landslides buried parts of the Kurshab-Jalpaktash asphalt road and the PAD-Budalyk 
gravel road, and significantly damaged the Chalma-Buyga road. In Chui, mudslides destroyed 
three bridges and about 2 km of the Natural Park Ala-Archa road. Floods also washed away 
numerous sections of the Barpy-Yrisuu-Changent road in Jalal-Abad, and destroyed the bridges 
on the Ilichevka-Erkintoo road in Osh and the Sovetskaya-Syrzavod road in Issyk-Kul. 
 
10.  Electricity. About 57 km of 35-, 10-, and 0.4-kilovolt (kV) power lines and nine electrical 
transformer stations were damaged in Chui and Osh oblasts. In the Uzgen district of Osh, 
landslides and mudslides buried the 35-kV Uzgen-Zerger and Mirza-Aki-Salamalik overhead 
lines and several 10-kV overhead lines. Floods and mudslides also partly destroyed the 10-kV 
Gulcha-Sopu-Korgon  overhead  line  in  Alay  district,  and  damaged  several  10-  and  0.4-kV 
overhead lines and transformer stations in the districts of Karasuu, Chon-Alay, and Ksara-Kulja.

In Chui, eight 35- and 10-kV lines and three transformer stations were seriously damaged by the 
mudslides. Many communities lacked electricity.  
 
11.  Schools. Thirty-two schools were destroyed or damaged, particularly in the oblasts of 
Chui, Jalal-Abad, and Osh. A number of school buildings collapsed, while others severely 
deteriorated as a result of heavy rains: the foundations of the buildings subsided and the walls 
are saturated with serious cracks. The Ministry of Ecology and Emergency Situations (MEES) 
has declared these school buildings “unsafe”, and ordered them to be vacated. Currently, 
children  are  studying  in  tents  or  other  temporary  locations  such  as  kindergartens,  with 
overcrowded and unheated classrooms. Because some damaged schools are located in areas 
at high risk of future landslides and floods, new schools need to be built in safer areas. 
 
12.  Damage to public infrastructure severely disrupted economic activity and social life in 
affected communities. The destruction of roads and bridges isolated thousands of people and 
hampered their access to food, drinking water, electricity, medical supplies, education, and 
health care. Some temporary roads have been formed and electricity restored using makeshift 
power lines, but these are vulnerable and even rainfall can destroy them. As the new school 
year began in September and winter has set in, damage to schools has disrupted normal 
learning and caused significant stress to children, teachers, and parents. There is an immediate 
need to rehabilitate and rebuild damaged infrastructure so as to restore economic and social 
activity in disaster-affected communities.  
 
13.  The Government responded actively in the aftermath of the natural disasters. On 13 May 
2003 the Government issued a resolution (No. 277) for urgent relief operations, and it has since 
mobilized its forces or contractors to restore essential services in affected areas. As of the end 
of August 2003, a total amount of Som174.1 million (about $4 million) had been allocated from 
the state budget to government ministries and agencies to support relief and rehabilitation. 
The Government also provided grants of Som379,000 (about $9,000) per household for victims 
of the most disastrous landslide in the Kara-Taryk village of Osh.8  The  Government  also 
extended long-term, interest-free credit9 of up to Som200,000 ($4,700) to each of other affected 
families to help relocate them to safer areas and allocated land for permanent resettlement 
centers. MEES is building two new resettlement centers (Kurshab-1 Resettlement Center10 and 
Dubitel Resettlement Center11) in Osh with government funding and it plans to build a third 
(Kurshab-2 Resettlement Center12). Because of the country’s severe fiscal constraints, the 
Government has the limited capacity to respond to the natural disasters and has therefore 
requested emergency assistance from the international community.

14.  There is an urgent need for ADB to help the Government cope with the natural disasters, 
especially given its constrained fiscal situation. Such assistance is consistent with ADB’s Policy 
on Rehabilitation Assistance After Disasters and would enable the Kyrgyz Republic to continue 
its  development  expenditures  that  otherwise  would  have  been  reallocated  for  disaster 
rehabilitation. In recognition of this, ADB fielded a fact-finding mission from 8 to 19 September 
2003 following receipt of the Government’s request for emergency assistance. The mission held 
discussions  with  the  central  and  concerned  local  governments,  affected  communities, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and other donor agencies. It also assessed the damage 
to public infrastructure. Based on the findings and understanding reached with the Government, 
the  mission  prepared  an  emergency  rehabilitation  project  for  possible  ADB  support.  The 
proposed loan is within the limits on the country’s public investment program required under the 
International Monetary Fund’s poverty reduction and growth facility.  
 
15.  External Assistance and Aid Coordination. Other international aid agencies have also 
responded to the country’s natural disasters. The United Nations and the United States Agency 
for International Development extended grants of $30,000 and $50,000, respectively, mainly in 
the form of food, medicine, tents, and blankets. Japan, the European Commission, and the 
Switzerland are providing grant assistance to strengthen the capacity of the central and selected 
local governments as well as local communities  to monitor, predict, and handle disasters. 
The  World  Bank  plans  to  reallocate  $3  million  from  an  ongoing  irrigation  loan  project  to 
rehabilitate damaged irrigation facilities, and has programmed  a $5 million natural disaster 
mitigation project for 2004 to help  develop a program to address key natural resource and 
environmental risks, including the impact of rock slides on uranium tailings stored in the Mailuu 
Suu area. There has been close coordination between ADB and the World Bank in response to 
the  Government’s  request  for  emergency  assistance.  Based  on  ADB’s  experience  in 
infrastructure and the World Bank’s involvement in the irrigation sector, it was agreed that ADB 
assistance would cover roads, bridges, power lines, schools, and municipal infrastructure while 
the  World  Bank  would  rehabilitate  damaged  irrigation  facilities  and  help  address  disaster 
prevention issues.  
 
16.  Lessons Learned. There are several important lessons learned from ADB operations in 
the Kyrgyz Republic First, the Government’s institutional capacity is generally limited by the 
frequent  changes  in  staff,  shortages  of  managerial  and  technical  skills  in  executing  and 
implementing agencies, as well as their limited familiarity with ADB’s operational policies and 
procedures. This has often led to delays in procurement, slow disbursements, and poor quality 
of work. Capacity building should be an integral part of ADB’s lending assistance. Second, 
inadequate  counterpart  funding  has  recently  affected  ADB’s  portfolio.  The  Government’s 
budgetary constraints and deficiency in its fiscal management system are the major factors, and 
these factors have resulted in implementation delays. Counterpart funding for individual projects 
needs close, regular monitoring.  
 
17.  ADB’s  previous  emergency  assistance  loans,  particularly  the  Flood  Emergency 
Rehabilitation Project for the Kyrgyz Republic,13 the Emergency Flood Rehabilitation Project14 
and the Emergency Baipaza Landslide Stabilization Project for Tajikistan,15 have provided a 
number of useful lessons. First, a strong government commitment to rehabilitation is essential to

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
18.  The immediate purpose of the Project is to assist the Government to restore economic 
and social activity quickly in the communities of four oblasts struck by landslides and floods by 
rehabilitating damaged public infrastructure. The long-term goal of the Project is to help sustain 
economic growth and poverty reduction in the country. The project areas cover the oblasts of 
Chui, Issyk-Kul, Jalal-Abad, and Osh. A project framework is provided in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Components and Outputs

Appendix 2: 
 
(i)  Roads  and  bridges.  Rehabilitating  five  damaged  roads  and  rebuilding  ten 
damaged bridges. The roads to be rehabilitated are the Natural Park Ala-Archa 
road in Chui; the Kurshab-Jalpaktash, PAD-Budalyk, and Chalma-Buyga roads in 
Osh; and the Barpy-Yrissu-Changent road in Jalal-Abad. Four bridges on the 
Barpy-Yrissu-Changent road, three on the Natural Park Ala-Archa road, and one 
bridge  each  on  the  Illichevka-Erkintoo,  Chalma-Buyga,  and  Sovetskaya-
Syrzavod roads will be rebuilt.  
 
(ii)  Electricity. Rehabilitating and rebuilding about 21 km on four damaged power 
distribution lines in Chui and Osh. Four damaged lines are (a) the 35-kV Uzgen-
Zerger line, (b) the 35-kV Mirza-Aki-Salamalik line, (c) the 10-kV Gulcha-Sopu-
Korgon line, and (d) the 10-kV Ala Archa-25 Years of Kyrgyzstan Substation line. 
Three damaged transformer stations located along the Ala Archa-25 Years of 
Kyrgyzstan Substation line will be replaced. 
 
(iii)  Schools. Building four schools in areas less prone to natural disasters in the 
oblasts of Chui and Osh, including furniture and facilities. 
 
(iv)  Municipal Infrastructure. Building municipal infrastructure in the Kurshab-1 and 
Dubitel  permanent  resettlement  centers  in  Osh,  which  the  Government  is 
establishing for disaster-affected people. Municipal infrastructure includes about 
4.3 km of on-site roads, 8.6 km of power lines, two electric substations, 4.3 km of 
water supply network, and about 1 km of drains. 
 
20.  The Project comprises 19 infrastructure subprojects, which have been selected from a 
long list of 52 subprojects provided by the Government, based on priorities established by the 
Government and agreed upon by ADB. The major selection criteria are the severity of damage 
and the impact of damaged infrastructure on the affected communities.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
24.  MEES will be the executing agency for the Project and will be responsible for oversight 
and coordination of implementation. A vice minister of MEES will be appointed project director 
responsible  for  implementation.  To  ensure  close  interagency  coordination  and  effective 
implementation, the executing agency will be assisted by a project steering committee (PSC), 
two implementing agencies, and two project implementation units (PIUs). 
 
25.  PSC will be established at the central government level to supervise overall project 
implementation. PSC will be chaired by the finance minister and will comprise representatives of 
concerned government agencies, including the prime minister’s office, MEES, MOEC, Ministry 
of  Transport  and  Communications  (MOTC),  the  State  Committee  on  State  Property 
Management and Attraction of Direct Investment, and project oblast governments. PSC will 
meet  on  a  quarterly  basis  to  review  progress  and  provide  guidance,  as  necessary,  on 
implementation. An organization chart of project implementation is provided in Appendix 4. 
 
26.  There will be two implementing agencies for the Project: MEES and MOTC. MEES will 
be responsible for implementing municipal infrastructure and school subprojects, while MOTC 
will handle roads, bridges, and electricity subprojects.  
 
27.  There will be two PIUs, one each at MEES and MOTC. The Government will establish a 
new  PIU  in  MEES,  and  will  use  the  existing  PIU  in  MOTC  under  the  ADB-funded Road 
Rehabilitation  Project.  PIUs  are  responsible  for  day-to-day  project  coordination  and 
implementation.  In  consultation  with  project  oblast  governments,  NGOs,  and  affected 
communities,  PIUs  will  coordinate  key  project  implementation  activities  such  as  detailed 
engineering design reviews, preparation of bidding documents, evaluation of bids, awarding of 
contracts, construction supervision, clearance of environmental examinations, and monitoring of 
implementation. A fulltime project manager will head each PIU, and will assist the project 
director for implementation.  
 
28.  Due to the urgency of the Project, the Government has undertaken design works for 
most of the subprojects. In addition to the technical viability of the Project, two major issues will 
need to be taken into account during detailed design. First, emphasis will be placed on disaster 
prevention because the Kyrgyz Republic is vulnerable to natural disasters. Since the World 
Bank and other donors will help the Government develop natural disaster prevention measures, 
ADB will incorporate  their  disaster prevention proposals  into  project  design  as  much  as 
possible. Second, special attention will be paid to the analysis of alternatives and least-cost 
solutions. Project consultants will review detailed designs and provide guidance, if necessary, to

the  executing  agency,  implementing  agencies,  and  PIUs  to  ensure  that  the  design  of  all 
subprojects is based on least-cost options, addresses rehabilitation needs, and meets medium-

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
38.  The Project will directly benefit disaster-affected communities in four oblasts of the 
Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  project’s  social  and  economic  benefits  include  rehabilitating  and 
rebuilding damaged roads and bridges, restoring disrupted power supply, building schools in 
less disaster-prone areas, and providing municipal infrastructure in permanent resettlement 
centers that the Government is setting up for disaster-affected people. More than 128,000 
people living in 78 villages will benefit. The Project will particularly benefit the poor because the 
majority of the population in disaster-affected areas is poor: the average poverty incidence for 
the four project oblasts is 44%. A proposal for grant assistance from the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  is  being  processed  separately  to  help  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  the  poor 
communities in disaster-affected areas. From a long-term perspective, the Project will contribute 
to achieving sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction in the country. 
 
39.  The Project is designed to rehabilitate damaged public infrastructure in affected areas in 
the shortest possible time. Given the relatively small size of individual subprojects, project 
benefits are not quantified. Nevertheless, the Project is strongly justified because it will help 
restore social and economic activity in disaster-affected communities. 
 
B.  Impacts 
40.  The Project will help bring social and economic life back to normal in disaster-affected 
communities. The rehabilitation of the damaged roads, bridges, and power lines will contribute 
to restoring the supply and distribution networks for basic goods and services. The construction 
of  four  schools  will  help  the  affected  children  regain  access  to  education.  Municipal 
infrastructure (e.g., on-site roads, power and water supply, and the drainage system) in the 
Kurshab-1  and  Dubitel  permanent  resettlement  centers  will  provide  a  sustainable  living 
environment for the affected families. The poor living in the remote areas will benefit directly 
from the Project because they are most affected by damaged infrastructure and disrupted social 
services.  
 
41.  While in principle ADB's safeguard policies apply to emergency projects, the urgency of 
this  Project  requires  fast-track  processing,  and  therefore  justifies  procedural  and  timing 
flexibility. An initial social assessment was conducted for all project components. A summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is provided in Appendix 8. 
 
42.  The Project does not require land acquisition or resettlement because components 
involve  rehabilitating  infrastructure  within  existing  rights-of-way  or  building  municipal 
infrastructure  within  the  new  resettlement  sites  that  are  the  State  property.  Some  106 
households in the villages of Kara-Taryk, Dubitel, and Changet  in Osh, whose houses were 
destroyed, are living in locations that the Government considers at high risk of future floods and 
landslides. The Government has allocated 23 hectares of land for the Kurshab-1 and Dubitel 
permanent resettlement centers in the same Uzgen district for voluntary resettlement of these 
affected families (see footnotes 10 and 11). The Government has also provided grants or long-
term, interest-free loans to help them rebuild houses at the resettlement sites. The Project will 
provide  municipal  infrastructure  in  these  two  sites.  The  fact-finding  mission’s  preliminary 
assessment shows that relocation to these two centers is voluntary, and that both project 
beneficiaries and host communities at the two sites are Kyrgyz. While there were no agricultural 
activities previously undertaken at the site of the Dubitel Permanent Resettlement Center, about

12  
1.85 hectares at the Kurshab-1 Permanent Resettlement Center had once been agricultural 
land.  The  Government  has  paid  a  total  of  Som18,492  (about  $440)  to  the  affected  host 
community ($235 per hectare), based on average annual output value. The affected host people 
are generally satisfied with the compensation. Prior to the construction of the ADB-financed 
subprojects in these two resettlements sites, a domestic consultant will conduct due diligence to 
assess  whether  the  affected  host  people  were  adequately  compensated  and  the  families 
already relocated did so on a voluntary basis. The consultant will also assist MEES to prepare a 
resettlement framework in compliance with ADB’s social safeguard policies, and implement 
mitigation  measures  as  required.  ADB  will  monitor  resettlement  and  implementation  of 
mitigation measures during review missions. ADB’s involvement in the permanent resettlement 
centers will improve the Government’s resettlement process.  
 
43.  A summary initial environmental examination (SIEE) was undertaken and is provided in 
Appendix 9. The Government agreed to give due attention to environment aspects of the 
Project, and will request MEES, MOTC, and other agencies concerned to undertake initial 
environmental  examinations  (IEE)  for  all  subprojects  according  to  ADB’s  environmental 
guidelines and the Government’s environmental standards and regulations. These agencies will 
also be required to follow mitigation measures outlined in the IEEs and SIEE during project 
implementation.  ADB  will  monitor  the  implementation  status  of  mitigation  measures  and 
environmental impacts of the Project through regular review missions as well as environmental 
status reports the Government will submit twice a year. 
 
C.  Risks 
44.  The Project involves four risks. First, there might be implementation delays because of 
MEES’  limited  capacity.  Project  consultants  will  assist  MEES  in  managing  project 
implementation. The proposed use of an existing PIU in MOTC will reduce the burden of MEES 
and mitigate this risk. Advance action on procurement, retroactive financing, and adoption of 
local competitive bidding and direct purchase will help reduce the risk of delayed procurement. 
Second,  construction  supervision  may  be  inadequate  because  the  Project  covers  several 
sectors and relatively small subprojects over a widespread area. This risk would be mitigated 
through adequate consulting services. Third, counterpart funds may not be provided in a timely 
manner.  ADB  will  work  closely  with  the  Government  to  ensure  that  sufficient  counterpart 
resources required for the Project are provided on a timely basis. ADB financing for part of the 
local currency cost would alleviate this risk. Fourth, fresh landslides and floods may damage 
completed project works. This risk would be mitigated through careful project design or new 
alignments to avoid areas at high risk of future landslides and floods. During implementation, 
ADB will coordinate with the World Bank and other donors, which will help the Government 
develop disaster prevention measures.

A.  Introduction  
 
1.  The  Ministry  of  Ecology  and  Emergency  Situations  (MEES)  is  conducting  initial

This document is a summary IEE (SIEE) based on the findings of an Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) fact-finding mission in September 2003. The mission visited proposed project sites and 
held discussions with the central and local governments, as well as representatives of affected 
communities. ADB has classified the Project under environmental category B. The mission 
prepared this SIEE for the Project with inputs from MEES, the ADB resident mission in the 
Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  domestic  consultants.  MEES  will  conduct  further  environmental

B.  Description of the Project 
 
2.  The Project will rehabilitate and reconstruct public infrastructure damaged by severe 
landslides and floods during the spring and summer of 2003. The project comprises four 
components covering four oblasts (provinces):  
 
(i)  Roads  and  Bridges.  Rehabilitating  five  damaged  roads  and  rebuilding  ten 
damaged bridges in Chui, Issyk-kul, Jalal-Abad, and Osh; 
(ii)  Power  Lines.  Rehabilitating  four  damaged  distribution  lines  totaling  
21 kilometers, and replacing three transformer stations in Chui and Osh;  
(iii)  Schools. Building four schools in Chui and Osh; and   
(iv)  Municipal  Infrastructure.  Constructing  on-site  roads,  power  supply,  water 
supply, and drainage systems in two resettlement centers in Osh. 
 
3.  The total project cost is estimated at $6.3 million equivalent, $5 million equivalent of 
which will be financed by an ADB loan. The Project will be implemented over 3 years, with 
completion scheduled for March 2007. 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
4.  The Kyrgyz Republic is extremely mountainous and contains some of the highest parts 
of the Tien Shan and Pamir Alay ranges. Its average elevation is approximately 2,750 meters, 
ranging from 500 meters in the Fergana Valley to 7,439 meters at Pobeda Peak. The mountains 
cover some 90% of the territory, with the forest cover representing only 4.25% of land area.  
The climate is classified as continental, varying with elevation, and can be subdivided into dry 
steppe, temperate steppe, and tundra. Temperature varies with elevation, with summer highs of 
40oC and winter lows below  –20oC. Precipitation also varies with elevation, with more than 
1,000 millimeters (mm) per year in the mountains and less than 230 mm per year in some 
valleys. Floods and landslides are major concerns because of seismic activity, steep slopes, 
fragile  soils,  and  human  activity.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  unique  in  Central  Asia  for  its 
concentration of wild plant and animal species. There are more than 500 species of vertebrates, 
including 83 species of mammals, 368 species of birds, 28 species of reptiles, 3 spices of 
amphibians, 75 species of fish, 3,000 species of insects, and more than 4,500 species of 
supreme  plants.  The  population  is  5  million  people,  65%  of  whom  reside  in  rural  areas.

7.  Potential impacts can be mitigated with good design and best engineering practices for 
noise abatement as well as dust and erosion control. Mitigation measures include (i) rock 
gabions, riprap, and stabilizing vegetation to minimize erosion; (ii) storm water retention basins 
to control contaminated run-off, if necessary; (iii) restriction of working hours to minimize noise 
disturbance; (iv) water spray to suppress dust at construction sites; (v) re-grading to return 
construction sites to natural contours, or engineered contours to minimize erosion and landslide 
potential; (vi) re-grading and revegetation of borrow pits; and (vii) designation of engineered 
disposal sites for waste that cannot be reused or recycled.   
 
8.  The Uzgen-Zerger power lines will be reconstructed along the existing right-of-way to 
minimize disturbance to nearby residents. A small patch of water-logged ground at Uzgen-
Zerger does not carry any ecological value or require protection. 
 
9.  Lowering  of  groundwater  at  the  Kurshab-1 Permanent Resettlement Center will be 
necessary for foundation stabilization, and will not have any long-term negative impacts on 
water quality or supply. Water supplies for schools and settlements will meet Kyrgyz water 
quality standards (or World Health Organization standards); MEES will determine if treatment 
systems are necessary.  
 
10.  The alignment of the Nature Park Ala-Archa road will be maintained after rehabilitation, 
as this is the only main access route for visitors. A new alignment bypassing the park is 
impractical considering the need to provide continued access to the park. The current alignment 
along the riverbed represents the most effective solution.  
 
11.  The Project does not require resettlement. 106 households in the villages of Kara-Taryk,

has allocated 23 hectares of land for the Kurshab-1 and the Dubitel resettlement centers in the

G.  Findings and Recommendations 
 
19.  The Project will rehabilitate roads, bridges, power lines, and schools. Adverse impacts 
on the environment will be small and limited to the construction period. The most important 
measures are proper disposal of construction debris and waste. Adverse impacts can be easily 
mitigated through good engineering and construction practices. No negative impact will persist 
during  operation.  The  Project  requires  no  resettlement.  Since  all  identified  adverse 
environmental impacts are minor and can be mitigated, an environmental impact assessment is 
not required. 
 
H.  Conclusions 
 
20.  The Project will have no direct negative impacts on water supply, sewerage, energy 
systems, or waste disposal. No impacts on archaeological or historic resources are expected; 
no significant adverse impacts on settlement patterns, provinces, or communities; and no 
significant adverse impacts to aquatic or terrestrial ecosystems are anticipated. Little or no 
agricultural displacement will occur. Construction materials—except special ones such as cable 
strands  and  admixtures—will  be  obtained  in  and  near  project  areas.  Embankment  soil, 
aggregates, and cement sources are available in or near project sites. No adverse impacts are 
seen on employment and income trends, nor on ethnic minorities.
